items.title: Generating metadata.json
items.body:
Is it possible to generate a matching TileJSON `metadata.json` to match a given vector tile produced with this library? I'm creating a server that is capable of serving `application/vnd.mapbox-vector-tile` output. I'm still in an early stage of development, and would appreciate an easy way to inspect my output and see if it is correct (literally just a single tile with a local directory, or localhost). There is a QGIS plugin that appears to be capable of this, but it demands a `metadata.json` file including layer names, attributes, a count of the number of features, geometry type, etc. It seems to me that this is all information I pass to the `encode` function before generating the tile itself. So would it be possible to use/extend this project to include the generation of a `metadata.json` file?

https://github.com/geometalab/Vector-Tiles-Reader-QGIS-Plugin/issues/181

items.title: ERROR ParseException: Unknown WKB type 79
items.body:
Hi All:
When I use encode, there are some errors **in the logfile.**
eg:
ERROR ParseException: Unknown WKB type 79(Maybe 73/69/85/other)

This is code:

`import mapbox_vector_tile
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO,
                    format="""%(asctime)s %(levelname)s %(message)s""",
                    datefmt='%d %b %H:%M:%S',
                    filename='nohup.out',
                    filemode='a')

lstaa = [{'name': 'landuse', 'features': [{'geometry': 'POLYGON((12919736.356835 4887077.83976072,12920078.4627125 4887230.62499933,12921631.3913512 4888136.66558616,12922138.25198 4888498.87675088,12922138.25198 4887077.83976072,12919736.356835 4887077.83976072))', 'id': 131103, 'properties': {'name_chn': 'aa', 'name': 'aa', 'ad_code': '110100', 'sort_rank': '200', 'lua_type': 2020, 'disp_class': 1, 'gid': 131103, 'name_eng': None}}]}]
aa = mapbox_vector_tile.encode(lstaa)

print 'start'
print aa
print '*'*20


bb = mapbox_vector_tile.decode(aa)
print bb
print 'game over'
`

But no error in the terminal, why?
Thanks!

items.title: Documentation seems to be truncated
items.body:
The readme contains this part:

```
      (x0, y0, x_max, y_max) = tile_bounds.extent
      x_span = x_max - x0
      y_span = y_max - y0
      def xy_pairs():
          for x_merc, y_merc in line:
              yield (
                  int((x_merc - x0) * MVT_EXTENT / x_span),
                  int((y_merc - y0) * MVT_EXTENT / y_span),
```
 The ```yield...```  statement is incomplete. Also the code that is calling ``xy_pairs()`` is missing.

items.title: Where to explain performance tips ?
items.body:
Hello,
in our struggle for performance we've found a cheap optimization : using the C++ version of protobuf instead of the python one. It's all decribed [here](https://github.com/google/protobuf/tree/v2.6.1/python) : just set two environment variables before you run your program (PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=cpp and ROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION_VERSION=2) and you get speedup for free (25 % in our usecase without quantization nor winding order). You might ask why version 2.6.1 ? Because we're on debian 8, and we use the same python package version than the apt python-protobuf package.

So, now my question is : is there somewhere in the project where we can leave track of this tip ?

items.title: Readme Encoding Example Error
quantize_bounds documentation problem
A Puzzle of Winding Order
items.body:
Hi there. I'm currently putting together a VectorTile (v2) codec, much like this library here but in another language. I found this while looking for an independant tool to verify my schema and the `protobuf` library I'm using. I've been experimenting with `mapbox-vector-tile` almost all day now, and so far I've managed the following:
- [x] Encode a hand-written instance of my schema type, and decode it with `mapbox-vector-tile`
- [x] Decode a tile of a single `Point` written by `mapbox-vector-tile` into my schema type
- [x] Decode a tile of a single `LineString` written by `mapbox-vector-tile` into my schema type

Initially I was having problems with how `geometries` were being encoded by `mapbox-vector-tile`, until I discovered `y_coord_down`. The next logical step was, of course, to attempt a `Polygon`. So, I encoded and wrote the following from python:

``` python
 vt = {
     "name": "OnePolygon",
     "features": [
         {
             "geometry":"POLYGON ((2 2, 5 4, 2 6, 2 2))",
             "properties": {}
         }
     ]
 }
```

while following the example from the README. Now, the points `(2,2) -> (5,4) -> (2,6) -> (2,2)` are in clockwise winding order (and also produce a positive area from the [surveyor's formula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoelace_formula)) _if_ we're working with y-down coordinates. So:

``` python
encoded = mapbox_vector_tile.encode([vt], y_coord_down=True)
```

I expected this `Polygon` to be encoded as: 

``` python
[ 
  9 4 4   # MoveTo(+2,+2) 
  18 6 4 5 4 # LineTo(+3,+2), LineTo(-3,+2)
  15  # ClosePath
]
```

but instead found it to be:

``` python
[
  9 4 4 # MoveTo(+2,+2) 
  18 0 8 6 3 # LineTo(+0,+4), LineTo(+3,-2)
  15 # ClosePath
]
```

which in fact represents: `(2,2) -> (2,6) -> (5,4) -> (2,2)`, the opposite winding of before. Despite defining the `Polygon` in clockwise order (in y-down space) as `POLYGON ((2 2, 5 4, 2 6, 2 2))`, the points were rearranged to form the counter-clockwise order. In v2 of the spec, this would be considered an interior ring, as it has negative area in y-down space.

How does this library handle winding order?

items.title: Decimal + quantize in _round() is substantially slower than round()
items.body:
In profiling this library, I have found that a very substantial amount of time is spent in the `_round()` method in encode.py.

Looking through git history, it looks like this change was made for python3 compatibility. I have done very little work with python3, any chance someone could explain the motivation for the change? Aside from even/odd rounding (is this particularly important?), is this functionally different than just calling `round()` on the `val`?
https://github.com/mapzen/mapbox-vector-tile/commit/24ab05b1f8c6093a2606f9a14527492846c590c9

For testing, I used a very large layers object that typically takes a little under 1s to encode. I ran 10 times to reduce noise (hence runtimes in the single digit seconds).

Here is the relevant cProfile output 

``` bash
         12019816 function calls (11938319 primitive calls) in 9.586 seconds

   Ordered by: cumulative time

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        1    0.011    0.011    9.586    9.586 profiler.py:1(<module>)
       10    0.001    0.000    9.281    0.928 __init__.py:11(encode)
      120    0.067    0.001    8.544    0.071 encoder.py:60(addFeatures)
    92100    0.227    0.000    3.980    0.000 encoder.py:55(_round)
     8400    0.047    0.000    3.366    0.000 encoder.py:197(addFeature)
     8400    0.029    0.000    3.328    0.000 encoder.py:122(quantize)
     8400    0.179    0.000    3.295    0.000 ops.py:184(transform)
     8400    0.198    0.000    2.617    0.000 encoder.py:360(_geo_encode)
    92100    0.493    0.000    2.348    0.000 decimal.py:2422(quantize)
    26600    0.069    0.000    2.115    0.000 encoder.py:125(fn)
   276306    0.514    0.000    1.459    0.000 decimal.py:515(__new__)
     8400    0.013    0.000    1.261    0.000 encoder.py:97(enforce_winding_order)
     1120    0.012    0.000    1.207    0.001 encoder.py:168(enforce_polygon_winding_order)
```

If we change `_round` to use the built in round like so:

``` python
def _round(self, val):
        return round(val)
```

This is the cProfile output: 

``` bash
         5916397 function calls (5834900 primitive calls) in 5.245 seconds

   Ordered by: cumulative time

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        1    0.009    0.009    5.245    5.245 profiler.py:1(<module>)
       10    0.000    0.000    4.821    0.482 __init__.py:11(encode)
      120    0.061    0.001    4.102    0.034 encoder.py:60(addFeatures)
     8400    0.042    0.000    2.007    0.000 encoder.py:197(addFeature)
     8400    0.154    0.000    1.306    0.000 encoder.py:360(_geo_encode)
     8400    0.024    0.000    1.122    0.000 encoder.py:122(quantize)
     8400    0.155    0.000    1.094    0.000 ops.py:184(transform)
     8400    0.038    0.000    0.924    0.000 encoder.py:297(_parseGeometry)
       10    0.000    0.000    0.718    0.072 python_message.py:807(SerializeToString)
       10    0.000    0.000    0.682    0.068 python_message.py:821(SerializePartialToString)
 19190/10    0.028    0.000    0.682    0.068 python_message.py:827(InternalSerialize)
   180/10    0.028    0.000    0.682    0.068 encoder.py:744(EncodeRepeatedField)
       13    0.060    0.005    0.550    0.042 __init__.py:1(<module>)
```

Happy to file a PR with this change, but would like to know more about the motivation in case I missed something.

items.title: A possible off-by-one error when flipping y coord
items.body:
Both the README and the spec v1 state that coordinates must be within 0 to 4095 i.e. `[0, EXTENT)`

When you flip the y coord, [the code](https://github.com/mapzen/mapbox-vector-tile/blob/master/mapbox_vector_tile/encoder.py#L408):

``` python
if not y_coord_down:
    y = self.extents - y
```

will convert `y=0` to `y=4096` which will cause a point feature at `y=0` (expected to show at the bottom of the tile) won't show up at all.

items.title: Raise an exception on geometries of GeometryCollection type
items.body:
Would be good if it could raise an exception to tell users that it doesn't support encoding GeometryCollection.

Otherwise protobuf will complain like this

``` python
collection = shapely.wkt.loads('GEOMETRYCOLLECTION (GEOMETRYCOLLECTION (POINT (4095 3664), LINESTRING (2889 0, 2889 0)), POINT (4095 3664), LINESTRING (2889 0, 2912 
158, 3757 1700, 3732 1999, 4095 3277))')
mvt.encode({'name': 'streets', 'features': [{'geometry': collection}]})

# TypeError: None has type <type 'NoneType'>, but expected one of: (<type 'int'>, <type 'long'>)
```

which doesn't make sense

items.title: spherical mercator assumption
items.body:
README.md states

> Per the specification, geometries are expected to be in spherical mercator projection before this transformations

The specification is actually projection-agnostic, working only in units within the extent. It's TMS numbering where the projection comes in.

items.title: Handle invalid geometries
items.body: After quantizing and encoding mvt tiles, we can end up in situations where we generate invalid geometries. The encoder should allow for the flexibility to handle these in different ways, eg drop invalid geometries, try to correct the geometry and try again, raise an exception, etc. Offering a callback might be a general way to approach the implementation.

items.title: Question about quantization in doc
items.body:
In your doc you metion you have to "pre-quantize" coordinates before passing them to the encoder
using something like:

``` python
MVT_EXTENT = 4096
xSpan = maxX - minX
ySpan = maxY - minY
xq = int((x - minX) * MVT_EXTENT / xSpan)
yq = int((y - minY) * MVT_EXTENT / ySpan)
```

but in the offical doc, it says: (https://github.com/mapbox/vector-tile-spec/tree/master/2.1)

```
Geometry data in a Vector Tile is defined in a screen coordinate system. The upper left corner of the tile (as displayed by default) is the origin of the coordinate system. The X axis is positive to the right, and the Y axis is positive downward. Coordinates within a geometry MUST be integers.
```

so downwards for `y` and initial coordinate starts at `(0,0)`.

Shouldn't you change it to:

``` python
MVT_EXTENT = 4096
xq = int((x - minX) * MVT_EXTENT / xSpan)
yq = MVT_EXTENT - int((y - minY) * MVT_EXTENT / ySpan)
```

I think that it would help performance if this library could take care of quantization by simply providing bounds and a layer name at initialization. We could then in the same loop that we are extracting the features add them gradually in a functional programming kind of style.

What do you think? I am willing to help out.

items.title: Tile extent should be 4096 inclusive
items.body:
From the [Mapbox spec](https://github.com/mapbox/vector-tile-spec/tree/master/2.1#41-layers):

```
A layer MUST contain an extent that describes the width and height of the tile in integer
coordinates. The geometries within the Vector Tile MAY extend past the bounds of the 
tile's area as defined by the extent. Geometries that extend past the tile's area as defined 
by extent are often used as a buffer for rendering features that overlap multiple adjacent
tiles.

For example, if a tile has an extent of 4096, coordinate units within the tile refer to 1/4096th
of its square dimensions. A coordinate of 0 is on the top or left edge of the tile, and a 
coordinate of 4096 is on the bottom or right edge. Coordinates from 1 through 4095 
inclusive are fully within the extent of the tile, and coordinates less than 0 or greater than 
4096 are fully outside the extent of the tile.  A point at (1,10) or (4095,10) is within the 
extent of the tile. A point at (0,10) or (4096,10) is on the edge of the extent. A point at 
(-1,10) or (4097,10) is outside the extent of the tile.
```

items.title: Encoding process is very slow for non clipped features
items.body:
Encoding process is very slow for non clipped features but if I use feature clipping by tile bounding box then encoding is performed very fast. Is it expected behavior? I can use clipping, but don't want to see tile bounds which appears in this case. Encoding time: first map - 70s, last - 10s.

![mvt](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/866124/12457704/ea5174a4-bfc7-11e5-9a40-ad86794c5438.png)

items.title: New Release to PyPI?
items.body: After the merge of #24, any possibility to push a new version? Probably needs a more major version bump given the change to the decoder API.

items.title: Render existing map instance to vector tile
items.body:
Essentially I am looking for a python equivalent to this flow in node:
https://github.com/mapnik/node-mapnik/blob/master/test/vector-tile.test.js#L42-L46

I have an existing map instance and would like to just set the map bbox and render to a vector tile protobuf. The current flow for raster tiles looks something like this:

``` python
m = Map(tilesize, tilesize)
load_map(m, stylesheet_path)

m.zoom_to_box(bbox)
img = Image(m.width, m.height)
render(m, img, scale)
```

Given that the readme discusses how to do the map->tile projections (https://github.com/mapzen/mapbox-vector-tile#coordinate-transformations-for-encoding), I am assuming this is not particularly straightforward. Any suggestions on the easiest way to get a mapnik Map into the format accepted by the encoder here?

items.title: Update for multi-polygon compliance with spec v1.0.2
items.body:
The upcoming spec v1.0.2 clarifies how multi-polygons should be encoded: all polygons should be "flattened" into one series of rings, with the winding order of the rings used to determine which are interior/exterior. An exterior ring indicates the start of a new polygon.

I believe this differs from our current handling of multi-polygons, where we "exploded" each polygon into its own feature, and copied the properties of each (as there was no official handling of multi-polygons previously). We should update to be compliant. Tangram already handles the new multi-polygon encoding so no client changes are needed on that side (style rules should be compatible with either method).

https://github.com/mapbox/vector-tile-spec/pull/36

items.title: pep8 compliance
items.body: Make a pass through all source files to ensure they are pep8 compliant. A circle.yml file should be added to enforce this going forward too.

items.title: python3 support?
items.body:
Just made a quick try, doesn't seem to work:
- relative imports
- protobuf 2.6 instead of 3.0alpha3 (which API seems to have changed a bit)

README says it's compatible. Do you have a hidden branch with the fixes or it's me missing something? :)

items.title: Update readme to use realistic geometry values
items.body: The readme example uses lat/lng coordinates, but we should probably send in values that we use in practice to avoid confusion. Or maybe just mention what kinds of values should be passed in for interoperability purposes.

items.title: In what projection should I provide geometries for encoding?
items.body:
Hi! I'm having some trouble with my vector tiles and I think I'm using the wrong projection. The example shows a WKT geometry in what appears to be latitude & longitude, but the vector tiles spec mentions both spherical mercator and pixel values. So here's my question:

When using `mapbox_vector_tile.encode()`, should I provide geometries in spherical mercator (meters), degrees latitude and longitude, or tile-relative pixels? 

Thanks!

items.title: reading tiles from file - invalid literal for int() with base 2: 'b10'
items.body:
I'm not sure if this is a documentation issue or a bug. 

I am trying to decode tiles from this source http://kartverket.maplytic.no/labs/ - for example http://cdn.maplytic.no/kartverket.maplytic.no/tile/sosi_n50,sosi_n250,sosi_n1000,sosi_n2000,sosi_n5000/13/4245/2423.vector.pbf?sosi_n250:zoom=10-11&sosi_n5000:zoom=0-4&sosi_n50:zoom=12-20&sosi_n2000:zoom=5-6&featuretype=%5BOBJTYPE%5D&sosi_n1000:zoom=7-9

These tiles are correctly decoded by mapbox gl. After downloading a tile from the server, I apply the decode method to the data read from file, as in 

```
data = open("tile.pbf","rb").read()
print mapbox_vector_tile.decode(data)
```

It yields the message 

```
invalid literal for int() with base 2: 'b10'
```

What is the correct way to read a vector tile from file?

items.title: MultiPolygons are incorrectly encoded as a single Polygon
items.body:
A MultiPolygon is being incorrectly encoded as a single Polygon. It appears the rings of the multipolygon are being flattened into one polygon, so for instance, a multipolygon with two single-ring polygons is being encoded as a single polygon with two rings, which means the second polygon is misinterpreted as a hole in the first polygon.

Instead, since the format doesn't natively support multipolygons, it probably makes the most sense to simply "denormalize" the multipolygon into multiple, individual polygon features, and copy the feature properties from the original multipolygon to each of the new individual polygons.
